importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The population of North Atlantic right whales declined by about 25% from 2010 to 2020, marking a period of severe decline that set the context for current recovery efforts.
A photograph of a pair of North Atlantic right whales interacting in Cape Cod Bay was used to illustrate the species' presence and behavior, highlighting their current ecological visibility.
A photo of a North Atlantic right whale in New England waters was used to visually represent the species' current status and location during migration.
The article reports a population estimate update on this date, indicating recent progress in conservation and recovery trends.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2010 to 2020 saw a 25% population decline in North Atlantic right whales, underscoring the urgency for conservation interventions.
The past four years show a slow but positive trend in population growth, suggesting resilience under conservation measures.

keyTakeAways: The North Atlantic right whale population has increased to an estimated 384 individuals, up from 376 in the previous year.
The population has grown by more than 7% since 2020, indicating a slow but positive recovery trend.
A key factor in recovery is the recent birth of four calves by mother whales and shorter breeding intervals among established females.
In total, 11 calves were born this year, which is below researchers' hopes but still encouraging due to the addition of new reproductive females.
The whales face ongoing threats from ship collisions and entanglement in fishing gear, especially as warming oceans force them to travel farther for food.
New management measures in Canada, particularly in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, have been critical to reducing mortality risks.
Scientists stress that sustained annual population growth is possible only if current conservation efforts are maintained.
Environmental groups warn that weakening marine protections, such as the Marine Mammal Protection Act, could jeopardize the species' recovery.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The North Atlantic right whale, one of the rarest and most endangered whale species, has shown a positive recovery trend with an estimated population now at 384 individuals, up from 376 in the prior year. This growth follows a 25% population decline from 2010 to 2020 and reflects sustained recovery over the past four years. Scientists credit new conservation efforts, especially in Canada’s Gulf of St. Lawrence, and improved reproductive patterns—such as increased calving rates and shorter breeding intervals—as key to this progress. However, threats like ship strikes and fishing gear entanglement remain significant, and environmental groups warn that weakening existing marine protections could reverse gains. Despite a modest number of calves this year, the entry of new females into the breeding pool offers hope for long-term survival.
title: North Atlantic Right Whale Population Shows Signs of Recovery Amid Conservation Efforts
